required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Qualitative Study for Pain Measurement Using Innovative Health Technology
clinical_study.official_title: Qualitative Study for Pain Measurement Using Innovative Health Technology (QualiPain)

brief_summary.textblock:
The present study is a multicenter, explorative, qualitative study. The primary endpoint of this study is to evaluate to which extent the collection of data with regard to pain caused by illness or treatment can be optimized using health technology solutions. For this evaluation semi-structured qualitative interviews with 8-10 patients will be conducted.
Secondary variables are the evaluation of the patients' pain experience and the general patients' willingness to collect data with regard to pain by using technological devices themselves or with support of healthcare professionals.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Willing to Assess Their Pain Using Technology
primary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were willing to assess their pain using technology.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Impaired by Pain During Daily Life
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were impaired by pain during their daily life.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Satisfied With Assessment of Pain Performed by Medical Staff Members
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were satisfied with the assessment of their pain when performed by medical staff members.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Considering Regular Assessment of Pain Important
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were considering regular assessment of their pain important.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Already Using Technology for Assessment of Pain or Other Medical Symptoms/Outcomes (e.g. Blood Pressure)
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were already using technology for assessment of pain or other medical symptoms/outcomes (e.g. blood pressure).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Willing to Assess Their Pain Themselves
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were willing to assess their pain themselves.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Willing to Assess Their Pain Using Technology, if Required by Treating Physician
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were willing to assess their pain using technology, if required by their treating physician.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Willing to Assess Their Pain Using Technology for Their Own Interest Only
secondary_outcome.description: Patients were asked during a semi-structured qualitative interview, if they were willing to assess their pain using technology, if this was for their own interest only.

study_pop.textblock:
Male and female patients with chronic or actue pain caused by illness or treatment. This pain has to be 4 or higher on a numeric ranking scale (0-10).
The inclusion of patients is planned according to the following sample design:
- Gender: male=3 patients; female=3 patients;
- Age: 18-49 years = 1 patient; 50-79 years = 1 patient; >80 years = 1 patient
- Quality of pain: acute: 2 patients; chronic: 2 patients

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or older
- Pain intensity > 4 (numeric ranking scale 0-10)
- Legal capacity
- Written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Lack of willingness to cooperate
- Lack of consent
- Lack of ability to follow instructions
- younger than 18 years

eligibility.gender_description: It is intended to have a balanced inclusion of at least 3 male and 3 female patients.

overall_official.affiliation: Dep. of Radiation Oncology, Univ. Medical Center S-H Campus Lübeck (Germany)

facility.name: Department of Neurosurgery, University Medical Center Schleswig-Holstein Campus Lübeck
Department of Radiation Oncology, University of Lübeck and University Medical Center Schleswig-Holstein

reference.citation: Wilkie DJ, Judge MK, Berry DL, Dell J, Zong S, Gilespie R. Usability of a computerized PAINReportIt in the general public with pain and people with cancer pain. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2003 Mar;25(3):213-24.

Tong A, Sainsbury P, Craig J. Consolidated criteria for reporting qualitative research (COREQ): a 32-item checklist for interviews and focus groups. Int J Qual Health Care. 2007 Dec;19(6):349-57. Epub 2007 Sep 14.

Jaatun, A. A. E. & M. G. Jaatun. 2016. Advanced Healthcare Services Enabled by a Computerized Pain Body Map. The 6th International Conference on Current and Future Trends of Information and Communication Technologies in Healthcare (ICTH 2016).
Kvale, S. & Brinkmann, S. 2009. Interview: Introduktion til et håndværk. Hans Reitzel Kbh.
Rubow, Cecilie. 2003. Samtalen som deltagerobservation. In: Ind i Verden. En Grundbog i Antropologisk Metode.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Patients With Acute or Chronic Pain
group.description: Patients included in this study must have had acute or chronic pain with an intensity of >4 on a numeric self-rating scale ranging from 0 to 10 (0=no pain, 10=maximum pain).

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
